title: Gay and Celibate: How to Belong to Two Different Tribes with David Bennett
description:
How can you reconcile all parts of your identity in an increasingly polarised landscape?
After a mystical experience in a Sydney bar, David Bennett found himself shifting from queer theory and student politics towards a surprising new centre of gravity: the Christian faith. Today he describes himself as a gay/ same sex-attracted celibate Christian, someone living between two tribes often assumed to be incompatible.

In this deep and tender conversation, theologian David speaks with Elizabeth Oldfield about his long wrestle with desire, queer identity and Scripture; why he believes celibacy can be liberating rather than repressive; and how he hopes to build bridges across an increasingly polarised landscape.

They explore what happens when your story becomes symbolic in the culture wars, how to refuse weaponisation from both left and right, and what it means to live as a pilgrim - someone always on the way, always becoming.

title: 5 Magic Questions to Start a Deep Conversation ‚ú®
description:
Maybe it's just me, but I get so bored and restless having to do the usual small talk when I meet new people.
 
I have found that asking good questions can be a saving grace to get me out of surface level conversations and into conversations that I actually want to have. It's like magic. Here's some of mine:
 
1. What is Sacred to you? One we use on the podcast, a way of getting deep quick, people can take this in any direction they like
 
2. What do you want people to say about you at your funeral? Can be intense but talking about death is never boring
 
3. What did you want to be when you grew up? A lovely way to encounter someone's childhood self, can get melancholy or juicy, that's why I love it
 
4. What do you love? Fall in love with them by hearing them talk about what they love. This one can even be used for flirting (you're welcome)
 
5. What's been on your mind lately?
 
Let me know how it goes if you end up using these. Do you have any others?
 
- Elizabeth

title: We Need More Resilience...
description:
I‚Äôm getting back on my skates - even though I‚Äôm nervous, even though I had a pretty bad fall last time. Even though a tall clumsy woman in her 40s should maybe find another hobby. 

Why? Partly because skating is brilliant. It makes me feel amazing. 

But also because it‚Äôs become a kind of exposure therapy. A way of reminding my body that fear and discomfort aren‚Äôt the same as danger. 

Through helping my child with a phobia of dogs, I‚Äôve learnt this key truth: When we withdraw every time something makes us feel tense, when we move away or unfollow or ghost‚Ä¶ we teach our bodies that difference is danger. That disagreement is something to run away from. It is the opposite of building resilience. 

Sometimes we do need to protect ourselves, but often we can practice staying. Feeling the fear and doing it anyway. Being around or even listening to people who are not like us. It sends a message to our bodies that we can tolerate this, actually. We are braver than we think. 

And as our instinctive threat reaction ebbs, we might find ourselves somewhere really interesting. 

This ability is the only way we can hold together any kind of common life.

What‚Äôs something you‚Äôre trying to stay with even though it‚Äôs hard? Let me know in the comments, we read them all üëá

- Elizabeth

description:

But I‚Äôve been trying to notice this feeling more and stopping myself. Because when I‚Äôm in that reactive space, I can‚Äôt be curious. I can‚Äôt be empathetic. I am not open to learn.

There might be something in that email I need to hear‚Ä¶ but not now, maybe later.

This, to me, is what the line ‚Äúturn the other cheek‚Äù sometimes means. Not weakness, not passivity, but a brave resistance to the urge to strike back or run away. A refusal to let my reactivity rule.

title: If you actually care about changing someone‚Äôs mind... #podcast
description:
If you actually care about changing someone‚Äôs mind, you have to do the work‚Ä¶

I want to be the kind of person who can cross tribal lines. Someone who can listen to people I disagree with and talk about our differences without things immediately getting tense. 

On some topics, I also really care about changing people‚Äôs minds!

I loved what Caitlin Moran said about choosing to write for The Times, rather than a paper she might be more politically at home on, so that she could be communicating with people who might disagree with her. She opens her columns with storytelling as a way of gently disarming those who might otherwise be put off. She finds ways to invite people in, not push them away. She creates a hospitable place for difference, rather than a hostile one.

Preaching to the choir, performing to our ‚Äúown side‚Äù by slamming our opponents is MUCH more immediately satisfying. We get a dopamine hit from the affirmation and a high from the self-righteousness (or at least I do). Sadly, while we can pretend we are virtuous for displaying the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù views, it usually actually makes this worse, hardening people who might disagree with us into their positions.

Caitlin and others who are trying to build a bigger tent, a more expansive sense of ‚Äúus‚Äù have to forgo those rewards for the sake of the long slow work of building bridges. I think we should celebrate them. What do you think?

- Elizabeth

title: I can't stop looking for people like me  #podcast
description:
Without meaning to, I am scanning the world for people who feel like me.
 
I‚Äôve found myself coming back again and again to this concept. Social scientists call it homophily or ‚Äòpeople like me syndrome‚Äô.
 
It‚Äôs the deep, often unconscious preference for people who remind us of ourselves. We scan the world looking for fragments of our own reflection. When we find it, we feel warm. We relax. We connect. We feel safe.
 
Of course, the opposite is true too. When someone doesn‚Äôt seem like us, we‚Äôre more likely to withdraw. But we can notice it, name it, and gently resist it.
 
If you find yourself drawn to someone - on the street, at work, or on social media - just pause and ask: Do they remind me of me?
 
And if you find yourself withdrawn from someone, Go digging for the one thing you have in common, however small. It really helps.
 
-Elizabeth

description:
John Vervaeke is professor of Psychology and Cognitive Science at the University of Toronto. He is also the host of the popular YouTube channel (@johnvervaeke) where he explores what he has coined the #meaningcrisis.

John spoke about his upbringing in a fundamentalist Christian home and what he has learned from that experience after time in therapy, relationships and the nature of reality, and the rehoming of spiritual practises outside of "legacy religions".

Find out more about John's work here: https://johnvervaeke.com

title: Tea Uglow on the Clash Between Tech Convenience and Personal Development
description:
This is a clip from Elizabeth Oldfield's conversation with Tea Uglow on The Sacred podcast.

Tea Uglow is the former Creative Director for Google's Creative Labs in Sydney and one of Deloitte's #OUT50 LGBTI+ Leaders for 2018. They are also the author of the books 'A Curiosity of Doubts' and 'Loud and Proud: LGBTQ+ Speeches that Empower and Inspire'.

Tea spoke about their childhood, prior to transitioning, and the difficulties of growing up during Margaret Thatcher's Section 28 legislation in the UK. They also spoke about the influence of technology in our lives, the power it has to shape our society and where we might have missed the boat on legislating Artificial Intelligence.

description:

Thordis Elva on forgiving the man who s*exually assaulted her
The Power of Forgiveness in an Age of "Cancel" Culture with Thordis Elva
description:
*EPISODE DISCLAIMER*
This episode was recorded before brand allegations emerged. It feels very timely but also potentially a difficult time for us to be releasing it. In the end, we wanted to leave as is because Thordis and her story is about more than sexual violence, and because the topic of sexual violence itself is about more than one person and their story. But we're also very aware there are a lot of complex and conflicting thoughts following the allegations emerging. So as ever please do get in touch and let us know your thoughts.

This is a clip from Elizabeth Oldfield's conversation with Thordis Elva on The Sacred podcast.

Thordis Elva is a writer and speaker best known for her powerful story of forgiving and reconciling with her rapist, Tom. Her Ted Talk, given alongside Tom, has been viewed over six million times.

Thordis spoke about her story of sexual assault and journey to forgiveness, the challenge of recognising the human nature of those who hurt you, and the uniting force that is hope.

Watch Thordis' Ted talk here: https://www.ted.com/talks/thordis_elva_and_tom_stranger_our_story_of_rape_and_reconciliation

Buy a copy of Thordis' book, South of Forgiveness, here: https://www.waterstones.com/book/south-of-forgiveness/thordis-elva/tom-stranger/9781911344056

description:

Zing Tsjeng is the editor in chief of Vice UK. She is the author of the book series 'Forgotten Women' which profiles underrated historical women in various fields, and is the host of the BBC podcast United Zingdom.

She spoke about her experience of growing up in Singapore and the way in which the government monitor the media, what she feels Vice UK's role and unique voice is, and the many problematic stereotypes around ESEA (East and Southeast Asian) identities.

Listen to the full episode here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=VHwp9zs1nwQ
